elements.content: Two cadmium­(II) metal–organic frameworks based on two mixed ligands of HBTA and H2BDC, [Cd5(BTA)6(BDC)2(DMF)4(H2O)2] n ·n(2DMF·H2O) (1) and [Cd7(BTA)2(BDC)6(DMF)8] n ·2nDMF (2) (HBTA = 1,2,3-benzenetriazole; H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), have been prepared through methods of liquid to liquid diffusion and solvothermal reaction, respectively. The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that both MOFs are constructed from cadmium clusters. In 1, six BTA– anions connect five Cd­(II) ions to generate a tetrahedral Cd5 cluster, which further links with four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2– bridges, forming a (4,4)-connected two–dimensional (2D) layer structure. In 2, each BTA– anion connects three Cd­(II) ions to generate a triangular Cd3 cluster, which further links with four Cd3 clusters and two 3-connected BDC2– anions, forming a (3,6)-connected three-dimensional (3D) framework. The results of photoluminescent measurements illustrate that in the solid state, both 1 and 2 can emit fluorescence at 465 and 450 nm, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Two cadmium(II) metal-organic frameworks based on two mixed ligands of HBTA and H2BDC, [Cd5(BTA)6(BDC)2(DMF)4(H2O)2] n ⋅n(2DMF⋅H2O) (1) and [Cd7(BTA)2(BDC)6(DMF)8] n ⋅2nDMF (2) (HBTA = 1,2,3-benzenetriazole; H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), have been prepared through methods of liquid to liquid diffusion and solvothermal reaction, respectively. The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that both MOFs are constructed from cadmium clusters. In 1, six BTA- anions connect five Cd(II) ions to generate a tetrahedral Cd5 cluster, which further links with four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2- bridges, forming a (4,4)-connected two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. In 2, each BTA- anion connects three Cd(II) ions to generate a triangular Cd3 cluster, which further links with four Cd3 clusters and two 3-connected BDC2- anions, forming a (3,6)-connected three-dimensional (3D) framework. The results of photoluminescent measurements illustrate that in the solid state, both 1 and 2 can emit fluorescence at 465 and 450 nm, respectively.

elements.content: Two cadmium­(II)-cluster-based metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been successfully constructed using HBTA as cluster-building ligand and H2BDC as bridging ligand. 1 is a 2D layer MOF containing perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear Cd5 clusters, and 2 is a 3D MOF containing triangular trinuclear Cd3 clusters.
elements.clean_text: Two cadmium(II)-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been successfully constructed using HBTA as cluster-building ligand and H2BDC as bridging ligand. 1 is a 2D layer MOF containing perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear Cd5 clusters, and 2 is a 3D MOF containing triangular trinuclear Cd3 clusters.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) based on metal cluster are of great interest to coordination chemistry researchers. The reasons can be mainly summarized as the following four aspects: (1) metal-cluster-based MOFs often show intriguing architectures and network topologies; (2) the poly nuclear cluster, with large steric volume, is beneficial to generate noninterpenetrated MOFs with large solvent accessible volume; (3) metal-cluster-based MOFs usually show better thermal stability in contrast to MOFs constructed from single metal as node; (4) due to the synergic activity among ions, metal-cluster-based MOFs may exhibit better functions. Despite metal-cluster-based MOFs show such a lot superiorities, to rationally design and synthesize MOFs with unique metal-clusters is still a challenge. Recently, there are two main approaches for constructing metal-cluster-based MOFs. One is using multidentate carboxylate ligands as spacers. The other is utilizing mixed ligands, usually including a small multidentate ligand and a long bridging ligand. The small multidentate ligand with multicoordination sites can connect ions together to form poly nuclear metal clusters, and the long bridging ligand can bridge these metal clusters and extend the cluster to 3D structure.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on metal cluster are of great interest to coordination chemistry researchers. The reasons can be mainly summarized as the following four aspects: (1) metal-cluster-based MOFs often show intriguing architectures and network topologies; (2) the poly nuclear cluster, with large steric volume, is beneficial to generate noninterpenetrated MOFs with large solvent accessible volume; (3) metal-cluster-based MOFs usually show better thermal stability in contrast to MOFs constructed from single metal as node; (4) due to the synergic activity among ions, metal-cluster-based MOFs may exhibit better functions. Despite metal-cluster-based MOFs show such a lot superiorities, to rationally design and synthesize MOFs with unique metal-clusters is still a challenge. Recently, there are two main approaches for constructing metal-cluster-based MOFs. One is using multidentate carboxylate ligands as spacers. The other is utilizing mixed ligands, usually including a small multidentate ligand and a long bridging ligand. The small multidentate ligand with multicoordination sites can connect ions together to form poly nuclear metal clusters, and the long bridging ligand can bridge these metal clusters and extend the cluster to 3D structure.

elements.content: 1,2,3-Benzenetriazole (HBTA), containing three N atoms in the five-member ring, has been proved an ideal building block for forming metal clusters in the assembly of MOFs. Zheng group found that HBTA can link Co­(II)/Ni­(II) ions together to form a tetrahedral metal clusters. Wang and co-workers found HBTA can link five Zn­(II) ions together to yield a similar tetrahedral metal clusters, which can be extended to 3D diamond networks by aromatic carboxylate bridging ligands. Encouraged by these successful works, we also chose HBTA as the building unit to generate metal clusters. Meanwhile, to ensure the articulation of the clusters into an extended three-dimensional framework, a rigid, linear linker of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) is used concurrently. In this article, we report two cadmium­(II)-cluster-based metal–organic frameworks with this two mixed ligands of HBTA and H2BDC, [Cd5(BTA)6(BDC)2(DMF)4(H2O)2] n ·n(2DMF·H2O) (1) and [Cd7(BTA)2(BDC)6(DMF)8] n ·2nDMF (2). Their syntheses, structures, and luminescent properties have been investigated and discussed.
elements.clean_text: 1,2,3-Benzenetriazole (HBTA), containing three N atoms in the five-member ring, has been proved an ideal building block for forming metal clusters in the assembly of MOFs. Zheng group found that HBTA can link Co(II)/Ni(II) ions together to form a tetrahedral metal clusters. Wang and co-workers found HBTA can link five Zn(II) ions together to yield a similar tetrahedral metal clusters, which can be extended to 3D diamond networks by aromatic carboxylate bridging ligands. Encouraged by these successful works, we also chose HBTA as the building unit to generate metal clusters. Meanwhile, to ensure the articulation of the clusters into an extended three-dimensional framework, a rigid, linear linker of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) is used concurrently. In this article, we report two cadmium(II)-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks with this two mixed ligands of HBTA and H2BDC, [Cd5(BTA)6(BDC)2(DMF)4(H2O)2] n ⋅n(2DMF⋅H2O) (1) and [Cd7(BTA)2(BDC)6(DMF)8] n ⋅2nDMF (2). Their syntheses, structures, and luminescent properties have been investigated and discussed.

elements.content: All of the chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined using Elementar Vario EL elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded in the 4000–400 cm–1 region using KBr pellets and a Bruker EQUINOX 55 spectrometer. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on NetzschTG-209 Thermogravimetry Analyzer in air atmosphere. The Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on D8 ADVANCE X-ray Diffractometer. Photoluminescent measurements were conducted on a RF-5301PC Spectrofluorophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Remarks

All of the chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined using Elementar Vario EL elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded in the 4000-400 cm-1 region using KBr pellets and a Bruker EQUINOX 55 spectrometer. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on NetzschTG-209 Thermogravimetry Analyzer in air atmosphere. The Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on D8 ADVANCE X-ray Diffractometer. Photoluminescent measurements were conducted on a RF-5301PC Spectrofluorophotometer.

elements.content: A DMF solution (5 mL) of H2BDC (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was layered with a DMF solution (10 mL) of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and HBTA (0.012 g, 0.1 mmol) at room temperature. After about two weeks, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis formed. Yield: 0.018 g, 42% based on Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C70H80N24O17Cd5: C, 40.20; H, 3.86; N, 16.07. Found: C, 40.06; H, 3.79; N, 16.11. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3064­(w), 2978­(w), 2825­(w), 2666­(w), 2548­(w), 1970­(w), 1677(s), 1572­(m), 1512­(m), 1420(s), 1286(s), 1135­(m), 1114­(m), 1012­(w), 941­(m), 876­(m), 781­(m), 726(s), 564­(w), 525­(m), 446­(w).
elements.clean_text:
[Cd5(BTA)6(BDC)2(DMF)4(H2O)2] n ⋅n(2DMF⋅H2O) (1)

A DMF solution (5 mL) of H2BDC (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was layered with a DMF solution (10 mL) of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and HBTA (0.012 g, 0.1 mmol) at room temperature. After about two weeks, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis formed. Yield: 0.018 g, 42% based on Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C70H80N24O17Cd5: C, 40.20; H, 3.86; N, 16.07. Found: C, 40.06; H, 3.79; N, 16.11. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3064(w), 2978(w), 2825(w), 2666(w), 2548(w), 1970(w), 1677(s), 1572(m), 1512(m), 1420(s), 1286(s), 1135(m), 1114(m), 1012(w), 941(m), 876(m), 781(m), 726(s), 564(w), 525(m), 446(w).

elements.content: A mixture of 0.5 mmol (0.154 g) Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, 0.5 mmol (0.060 g) HBTA, 0.5 mmol (0.083 g) H2BDC and 12 mL DMF was heated at 110 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure in a sealed 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. After the autoclave was cooled over a period of 16 h at a rate of 5 °C·h–1, colorless block crystals of 2 were isolated by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 0.112 g, 57% based on Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C90H102N16O34Cd7: C, 39.47; H, 3.75; N, 8.18. Found: C, 39.41; H, 3.80; N, 8.14. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3414­(m), 1658­(m), 1556(s), 1501­(w), 1390(s), 1201­(w), 1150­(w), 1104­(w), 1012­(m), 928­(w), 883­(w), 840­(m), 746(s), 635­(w), 525­(m).
elements.clean_text:
[Cd7(BTA)2(BDC)6(DMF)8] n ⋅2nDMF (2)

A mixture of 0.5 mmol (0.154 g) Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, 0.5 mmol (0.060 g) HBTA, 0.5 mmol (0.083 g) H2BDC and 12 mL DMF was heated at 110 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure in a sealed 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. After the autoclave was cooled over a period of 16 h at a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1, colorless block crystals of 2 were isolated by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 0.112 g, 57% based on Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C90H102N16O34Cd7: C, 39.47; H, 3.75; N, 8.18. Found: C, 39.41; H, 3.80; N, 8.14. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3414(m), 1658(m), 1556(s), 1501(w), 1390(s), 1201(w), 1150(w), 1104(w), 1012(m), 928(w), 883(w), 840(m), 746(s), 635(w), 525(m).

elements.content: Single-crystal data for 1 and 2 were collected at 173 K on an Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer with the Enhance X-ray Source of Cu radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures were solved by heavy atom methods, which yielded the positions of all nonhydrogen atoms. These were refined first isotropically and then anisotropically. All the hydrogen atoms of the ligands and the coordination DMF molecules were placed in calculated positions with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in structure factor calculations in the final stage of full-matrix least-squares refinement. The hydrogen atoms of the lattice H2O molecule in 1 and disordered DMF molecules in 2 were not added. The disordered parts were restrained using DFIX, DELU, and SIMU instructions to make the displacement parameters more reasonable. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL system of computer programs. The crystallographic data for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal data for 1 and 2 were collected at 173 K on an Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer with the Enhance X-ray Source of Cu radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures were solved by heavy atom methods, which yielded the positions of all nonhydrogen atoms. These were refined first isotropically and then anisotropically. All the hydrogen atoms of the ligands and the coordination DMF molecules were placed in calculated positions with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in structure factor calculations in the final stage of full-matrix least-squares refinement. The hydrogen atoms of the lattice H2O molecule in 1 and disordered DMF molecules in 2 were not added. The disordered parts were restrained using DFIX, DELU, and SIMU instructions to make the displacement parameters more reasonable. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL system of computer programs. The crystallographic data for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  Table S1.

R 2 = [Σ­[w(F o 2 – F c 2)2]/Σw(F o 2)2]1/2, w = 1/[σ2 (F o )2 + (aP)2 + bP ], where P = [(F o 2) +2F c 2]/3.

With the same reactants, the same ratio of reactants, and the same reaction solvent, we using two different synthesis strategies fabricated two cadmium­(II)-cluster-based MOFs with completely different structures. In both MOFs, the BTA– ligands serve as good cluster-building units and the BDC2– ligands act as good bridges, which is consistent with our initial designing. This result implies when selecting special topic ligands, there is some possibility to rationally design and synthesize MOF materials.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation

With the same reactants, the same ratio of reactants, and the same reaction solvent, we using two different synthesis strategies fabricated two cadmium(II)-cluster-based MOFs with completely different structures. In both MOFs, the BTA- ligands serve as good cluster-building units and the BDC2- ligands act as good bridges, which is consistent with our initial designing. This result implies when selecting special topic ligands, there is some possibility to rationally design and synthesize MOF materials.

elements.content: The infrared spectra (IR) of 1 and 2 are depicted in Figure S1, and the main adsorption peaks are listed in the . Obviously, the strong adsorption peaks at 1677 cm–1 for 1 and 1658 cm–1 for 2 should be assigned to the stretching resonance of CO bonds of carboxylic groups and DMF molecules, and the peaks at 1420, 1512, 1572 cm–1 for 1, 1390, 1501, 1556 cm–1 for 2 can be attributed to the skeleton resonances of the aromatic rings and triazolate rings. It should be noted that a strong and sharp peak at 1286 cm–1 for 1 is observed, this adsorption peak can be assigned to the stretching resonance of C–O bond of the monodentate carboxylic group. However, similar adsorption peak is not observed for 2, which indicates in 2, all the O atoms of carboxylic groups coordinate with Cd­(II) ions. These results reveal that the BDC2– anions employ different coordination modes in 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectra (IR) of 1 and 2 are depicted in  Figure S1, and the main adsorption peaks are listed in the . Obviously, the strong adsorption peaks at 1677 cm-1 for 1 and 1658 cm-1 for 2 should be assigned to the stretching resonance of CO bonds of carboxylic groups and DMF molecules, and the peaks at 1420, 1512, 1572 cm-1 for 1, 1390, 1501, 1556 cm-1 for 2 can be attributed to the skeleton resonances of the aromatic rings and triazolate rings. It should be noted that a strong and sharp peak at 1286 cm-1 for 1 is observed, this adsorption peak can be assigned to the stretching resonance of C-O bond of the monodentate carboxylic group. However, similar adsorption peak is not observed for 2, which indicates in 2, all the O atoms of carboxylic groups coordinate with Cd(II) ions. These results reveal that the BDC2- anions employ different coordination modes in 1 and 2.

elements.content: The result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates 1 crystallizes in C2/c space group. There are two and a half crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ions in each asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure a, Cd1 is six-coordinated with six N atoms from six individual μ3-BTA– anions, forming an octahedral geometry. Cd2 and Cd3 show similar distorted N3O3 octahedral geometries. The three N atoms coordinated to Cd2/Cd3 come from three individual BTA– anions. The three O atoms around Cd2 come from one BDC2– anion (O1), one DMF molecule (O1D), and one H2O molecule (O1W), while these around Cd3 are from one BDC2– anions (O3 and O4) and one DMF molecule (O2D). One Cd1, two Cd2 and two Cd3 are connected together by six μ3-BTA– anions to generate a perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear cadmium­(II) cluster (Cd5 cluster), in which Cd1 locates the center of the tetrahedron, Cd2 and Cd3 occupy the four apical positions (Figure b). Each μ3-BTA– anion, straddling an edge of the tetrahedron, binds to three Cd­(II) ions through it is three N atoms of the triazole ring. It is worthy noting that many MOFs based on cadmium­(II) clusters have been reported in literatures to date; however, the one containing perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear cadmium­(II) cluster like in 1 has not been documented before this work.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

The result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates 1 crystallizes in C2/c space group. There are two and a half crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions in each asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure a, Cd1 is six-coordinated with six N atoms from six individual μ3-BTA- anions, forming an octahedral geometry. Cd2 and Cd3 show similar distorted N3O3 octahedral geometries. The three N atoms coordinated to Cd2/Cd3 come from three individual BTA- anions. The three O atoms around Cd2 come from one BDC2- anion (O1), one DMF molecule (O1D), and one H2O molecule (O1W), while these around Cd3 are from one BDC2- anions (O3 and O4) and one DMF molecule (O2D). One Cd1, two Cd2 and two Cd3 are connected together by six μ3-BTA- anions to generate a perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear cadmium(II) cluster (Cd5 cluster), in which Cd1 locates the center of the tetrahedron, Cd2 and Cd3 occupy the four apical positions (Figure b). Each μ3-BTA- anion, straddling an edge of the tetrahedron, binds to three Cd(II) ions through it is three N atoms of the triazole ring. It is worthy noting that many MOFs based on cadmium(II) clusters have been reported in literatures to date; however, the one containing perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear cadmium(II) cluster like in 1 has not been documented before this work.

elements.content: (a) The coordination environment of the Cd­(II) ions and the coordination modes of BTA– and BDC2– anions in 1; (b) The pentanuclear Cd5 cluster connected by six BTA– anions; (c) Each Cd5 cluster connects with four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2– bridges, forming a (4,4)-connected 2D layer structure; (d) The topology structure of 1; (e) The adjacent layers are stacked together through interlayer hydrogen bonds (R O1W···O4 = 2.811(9) Å), resulting in 3D supramolecular structure.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environment of the Cd(II) ions and the coordination modes of BTA- and BDC2- anions in 1; (b) The pentanuclear Cd5 cluster connected by six BTA- anions; (c) Each Cd5 cluster connects with four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2- bridges, forming a (4,4)-connected 2D layer structure; (d) The topology structure of 1; (e) The adjacent layers are stacked together through interlayer hydrogen bonds (R O1W⋅⋅⋅O4 = 2.811(9) Å), resulting in 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: The tetrahedral Cd5 cluster further connects to four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2– bridges (Scheme , Mode I) and extends to a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4)-connected layer (Figures c and d). The 2D layers are further stacked together through interlayer strong hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Figure e), with the hydrogen bonding distances of 2.811(9) Å (O1W···O4). To the best of our knowledge, although the tetrahedral pentanuclear Cu­(II)/Co­(II)/Ni­(II)/Zn­(II) clusters linked by BTA– anions have been observed in separate cluster complexes or 3D MOFs, similar metal cluster has not been observed in 2D layer MOFs so far.
elements.clean_text: The tetrahedral Cd5 cluster further connects to four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2- bridges (Scheme , Mode I) and extends to a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4)-connected layer (Figures c and d). The 2D layers are further stacked together through interlayer strong hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Figure e), with the hydrogen bonding distances of 2.811(9) Å (O1W⋅⋅⋅O4). To the best of our knowledge, although the tetrahedral pentanuclear Cu(II)/Co(II)/Ni(II)/Zn(II) clusters linked by BTA- anions have been observed in separate cluster complexes or 3D MOFs, similar metal cluster has not been observed in 2D layer MOFs so far.

elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination Modes of BDC2- Anions Observed in 1 and 2

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in P21/c space group. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 contains seven crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ions. The μ3-BTA– anions, like in 1, connect three Cd­(II) ions [(Cd1, Cd2, Cd3) or (Cd5, Cd6 Cd7)] to generate two similar triangular trinuclear cadmium­(II) cluster (Cd3 clusters), in which Cd1, Cd2, Cd5, Cd6 show similar NO6 pentagonal bipyramid geometries, and Cd3, Cd7 exhibit similar NO5 octahedral geometries (Figures b and c). The N atom coordinated with each Cd­(II) ion comes from μ3-BTA– anion. The six O atoms around Cd1/Cd5 are from three BDC2– anions and one DMF molecule, while these around Cd2/Cd6 fully come from four BDC2– anions. The five O atoms around Cd3/Cd7 come from three BDC2– anions and one DMF molecule. Cd4 also shows an octahedral geometry, which is completed by six O atoms from two BDC2– anions and four DMF molecules. The BDC2– anions assume three types of coordination modes (Scheme , Modes II, III, and IV), in which Mode III is symmetric, and Modes II and IV are asymmetric. Through the bridging of the BDC2– anions, the trinuclear Cd3 clusters and Cd4 ions are connected together to form a 3D metal–organic framework, in which the Cd4 ions locate the centers of the pores (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 crystallizes in P21/c space group. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 contains seven crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions. The μ3-BTA- anions, like in 1, connect three Cd(II) ions [(Cd1, Cd2, Cd3) or (Cd5, Cd6 Cd7)] to generate two similar triangular trinuclear cadmium(II) cluster (Cd3 clusters), in which Cd1, Cd2, Cd5, Cd6 show similar NO6 pentagonal bipyramid geometries, and Cd3, Cd7 exhibit similar NO5 octahedral geometries (Figures b and c). The N atom coordinated with each Cd(II) ion comes from μ3-BTA- anion. The six O atoms around Cd1/Cd5 are from three BDC2- anions and one DMF molecule, while these around Cd2/Cd6 fully come from four BDC2- anions. The five O atoms around Cd3/Cd7 come from three BDC2- anions and one DMF molecule. Cd4 also shows an octahedral geometry, which is completed by six O atoms from two BDC2- anions and four DMF molecules. The BDC2- anions assume three types of coordination modes (Scheme , Modes II, III, and IV), in which Mode III is symmetric, and Modes II and IV are asymmetric. Through the bridging of the BDC2- anions, the trinuclear Cd3 clusters and Cd4 ions are connected together to form a 3D metal-organic framework, in which the Cd4 ions locate the centers of the pores (Figure d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Cd­(II) ions and the coordination modes of BTA– and BDC2– anions in 2. (b and c) Two triangular trinuclear Cd3 clusters; (d) The 3D structure of 2 (ligands in green stand for BTA– anions, ligands in gray and yellow represent μ2- and μ3-BDC2– anions respectively, the coordinated DMF molecules are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and the coordination modes of BTA- and BDC2- anions in 2. (b and c) Two triangular trinuclear Cd3 clusters; (d) The 3D structure of 2 (ligands in green stand for BTA- anions, ligands in gray and yellow represent μ2- and μ3-BDC2- anions respectively, the coordinated DMF molecules are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: To well understand the structure of 2, the topological analysis method was used to simplify the structure. Obviously, The BDC2– anion in mode II/III linking two Cd3 clusters, should be considered as a connection ( Figures S1a and S1b), while the one in mode IV, not only bridging two Cd3 clusters, but also connecting another equivalent BDC2– anion through Cd4 ion, should been regarded as a three-connected node ( Figures S1c and 3a). The Cd3 cluster, connecting with four similar Cd3 clusters and two μ3-BDC2– anions, can be viewed as a six-connected node (Figure b). Therefore, the 3D metal–organic framework of 2 can be describe as a (3,6)-connected network, with the Schläfli symbol of {42·6}­{46·69} calculated by TOPOS 4.0 procedure (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: To well understand the structure of 2, the topological analysis method was used to simplify the structure. Obviously, The BDC2- anion in mode II/III linking two Cd3 clusters, should be considered as a connection ( Figures S1a and S1b), while the one in mode IV, not only bridging two Cd3 clusters, but also connecting another equivalent BDC2- anion through Cd4 ion, should been regarded as a three-connected node ( Figures S1c and 3a). The Cd3 cluster, connecting with four similar Cd3 clusters and two μ3-BDC2- anions, can be viewed as a six-connected node (Figure b). Therefore, the 3D metal-organic framework of 2 can be describe as a (3,6)-connected network, with the Schläfli symbol of {42⋅6}{46⋅69} calculated by TOPOS 4.0 procedure (Figure c).

elements.content: Schematic representation for the nodes of μ3–BDC2– anion (a) and Cd3 cluster (b). (c) The (3,6)-connected topological net of 2 (the atoms in yellow and purple represent the μ3-BDC2– anions and the triangular Cd3 clusters respectively).
elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic representation for the nodes of μ3-BDC2- anion (a) and Cd3 cluster (b). (c) The (3,6)-connected topological net of 2 (the atoms in yellow and purple represent the μ3-BDC2- anions and the triangular Cd3 clusters respectively).

elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was used to check the purity of the two compounds. As shown in Figure , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns at room temperature closely match to those in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data, which indicates single phases of them are formed. The TGA curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 23.3% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice DMF and H2O molecules, as well as the coordinated DMF and H2O (calcd 23.6%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 380 °C, followed by another two steps of weight losses after that temperature (Figure ). The TGA curve of 2 shows no marked platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated DMF molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches 350 °C, all the DMF molecules (calcd 26.7%) in 2 are lost (observed 27.0%). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose upon further heating.
elements.clean_text:
XPRD, Thermal Analyses, and Photoluminescent Properties

X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was used to check the purity of the two compounds. As shown in Figure , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns at room temperature closely match to those in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data, which indicates single phases of them are formed. The TGA curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 23.3% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice DMF and H2O molecules, as well as the coordinated DMF and H2O (calcd 23.6%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 380 °C, followed by another two steps of weight losses after that temperature (Figure ). The TGA curve of 2 shows no marked platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated DMF molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches 350 °C, all the DMF molecules (calcd 26.7%) in 2 are lost (observed 27.0%). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose upon further heating.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties for 1 and 2 are investigated in the solid state. As depicted in Figure , it can be observed that both 1 and 2 exhibit photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 330 and 345 nm, respectively. As the free ligands of HBTA and H2BDC can emit weak photoluminescence at 469 and 472 nm when excited at 341 and 364 nm respectively ( Figure S3), the emission peaks at 465 nm for 1 and 450 nm for 2 can be tentatively attributed to ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT).

elements.content: Using HBTA as cluster-building ligand and H2BDC as bridging ligand, we have successfully constructed two cadmium­(II)-cluster-based metal–organic frameworks. 1 is a 2D layer MOF containing perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear Cd5 clusters. 2 is a 3D MOF containing triangular trinuclear Cd3 clusters. Photoluminescent tests illustrate that both 1 and 2 can emit blue light in the solid state at ambient temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Using HBTA as cluster-building ligand and H2BDC as bridging ligand, we have successfully constructed two cadmium(II)-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks. 1 is a 2D layer MOF containing perfect tetrahedral pentanuclear Cd5 clusters. 2 is a 3D MOF containing triangular trinuclear Cd3 clusters. Photoluminescent tests illustrate that both 1 and 2 can emit blue light in the solid state at ambient temperature.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, the result of topology analysis for 2, table for the selected bond length and angle (Table S1), and IR spectra for 1 and 2, emission spectra for two free ligands. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

A DMF solution (5 mL) of H2BDC (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was layered with a DMF solution (10 mL) of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and HBTA (0.012 g, 0.1 mmol) at room temperature. After about two weeks, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis formed. Yield: 0.018 g, 42% based on Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C70H80N24O17Cd5: C, 40.20; H, 3.86; N, 16.07. Found: C, 40.06; H, 3.79; N, 16.11. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3064­(w), 2978­(w), 2825­(w), 2666­(w), 2548­(w), 1970­(w), 1677(s), 1572­(m), 1512­(m), 1420(s), 1286(s), 1135­(m), 1114­(m), 1012­(w), 941­(m), 876­(m), 781­(m), 726(s), 564­(w), 525­(m), 446­(w).

[Cd<sub>7</sub>(BTA)<sub>2</sub>(BDC)<sub>6</sub>(DMF)<sub>8</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·2<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>DMF (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of 0.5 mmol (0.154 g) Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, 0.5 mmol (0.060 g) HBTA, 0.5 mmol (0.083 g) H2BDC and 12 mL DMF was heated at 110 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure in a sealed 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. After the autoclave was cooled over a period of 16 h at a rate of 5 °C·h–1, colorless block crystals of 2 were isolated by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 0.112 g, 57% based on Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C90H102N16O34Cd7: C, 39.47; H, 3.75; N, 8.18. Found: C, 39.41; H, 3.80; N, 8.14. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3414­(m), 1658­(m), 1556(s), 1501­(w), 1390(s), 1201­(w), 1150­(w), 1104­(w), 1012­(m), 928­(w), 883­(w), 840­(m), 746(s), 635­(w), 525­(m).

[Cd7(BTA)2(BDC)6(DMF)8] n ⋅2nDMF (2)

cln_elements.content:
X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was used to check the purity of the two compounds. As shown in Figure , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns at room temperature closely match to those in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data, which indicates single phases of them are formed. The TGA curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 23.3% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice DMF and H2O molecules, as well as the coordinated DMF and H2O (calcd 23.6%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 380 °C, followed by another two steps of weight losses after that temperature (Figure ). The TGA curve of 2 shows no marked platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated DMF molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches 350 °C, all the DMF molecules (calcd 26.7%) in 2 are lost (observed 27.0%). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose upon further heating.

The photoluminescent properties for 1 and 2 are investigated in the solid state. As depicted in Figure , it can be observed that both 1 and 2 exhibit photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 330 and 345 nm, respectively. As the free ligands of HBTA and H2BDC can emit weak photoluminescence at 469 and 472 nm when excited at 341 and 364 nm respectively ( Figure S3), the emission peaks at 465 nm for 1 and 450 nm for 2 can be tentatively attributed to ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT).

XPRD, Thermal Analyses, and Photoluminescent Properties

The TGA curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 23.3% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice DMF and H2O molecules, as well as the coordinated DMF and H2O (calcd 23.6%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 380 °C, followed by another two steps of weight losses after that temperature (Figure ). The TGA curve of 2 shows no marked platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated DMF molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches 350 °C, all the DMF molecules (calcd 26.7%) in 2 are lost (observed 27.0%). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose upon further heating.

The photoluminescent properties for 1 and 2 are investigated in the solid state. As depicted in Figure , it can be observed that both 1 and 2 exhibit photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 330 and 345 nm, respectively. As the free ligands of HBTA and H2BDC can emit weak photoluminescence at 469 and 472 nm when excited at 341 and 364 nm respectively ( Figure S3), the emission peaks at 465 nm for 1 and 450 nm for 2 can be tentatively attributed to ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT).

(a) The coordination environment of the Cd­(II) ions and the coordination modes of BTA– and BDC2– anions in 1; (b) The pentanuclear Cd5 cluster connected by six BTA– anions; (c) Each Cd5 cluster connects with four equivalent Cd5 clusters through four BDC2– bridges, forming a (4,4)-connected 2D layer structure; (d) The topology structure of 1; (e) The adjacent layers are stacked together through interlayer hydrogen bonds (R O1W···O4 = 2.811(9) Å), resulting in 3D supramolecular structure.
